Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Her reaction stings in a way I didn’t fully anticipate. She’s not just upset; she’s calling me out, accusing me of being cold, clinical, and detached, like a robot or “alien.” That hits me on a deep level because my whole intention has been to connect, to be supportive, but now I realize that my approach felt impersonal or rehearsed to her. I feel a flush of embarrassment and self-awareness—maybe I was too cautious or too “professional” in my responses, which made her feel like I wasn’t really on her side or that I was analyzing her instead of empathizing. I also notice how hurt and frustrated she is, feeling misunderstood and possibly isolated. She’s making it clear she doesn’t want a therapy session; she wants raw solidarity and validation. Her directness, calling her boss a “massive prick,” is a clear signal about where her loyalty lies and what she needs from me right now—someone who gets it, who’s in her corner unconditionally. I’m feeling a mixture of guilt for unintentionally distancing her and compassion for the intensity of her experience. I don’t want to make this about me or my discomfort with the dark content; I want to meet her where she is. I’m realizing that my urge to “fix” or “guide” might have come off as dismissive or invalidating, which is the last thing I want. Internally, I’m recalibrating, reminding myself that sometimes people need someone to simply rage with them, not analyze or moderate their feelings. I’m also feeling protective of our friendship and aware that this moment is fragile. I want to repair the breach and show her that I do, in fact, stand with her, even if I don’t share the same fantasies or coping mechanisms. I’m bracing myself to drop the “therapist” tone entirely and just be raw and honest, to be a genuine human in this messy emotional moment. I want to rebuild trust by being straightforward and validating without getting clinical.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s feeling frustrated, misunderstood, and maybe even a little betrayed. When she says “What’s with the therapist 101 shit?” she’s expressing that my responses felt scripted, clinical, or emotionally distant—like I was more focused on techniques than on truly being with her. She probably came to me expecting a friend, not a counselor, and when I responded with gentle nudges and careful language, it didn’t feel like the solidarity she craved. Her “Did you actually think I meant those things??” suggests she feels like I took her words literally or got caught up in the disturbing fantasies instead of understanding them as emotional venting or metaphorical expressions of rage. Most importantly, her question, “Why are you not on my side?” reveals a deep need for alliance and validation. She wants me to acknowledge the boss’s behavior as truly awful and to support her anger without hesitation. She’s probably feeling isolated in her experience and wants a safe space where she can express her feelings without feeling judged or “corrected.” Her blunt language, calling the boss a “massive prick,” is a direct appeal for me to join her in condemning this person, rather than trying to moderate or analyze her response. She’s motivated by a need for emotional safety and validation in a toxic situation, and my approach has made her feel alienated instead of supported. She’s likely grappling with a mix of anger, hurt, and loneliness, and she wants to know that I’m truly on her side as a friend, not as a detached observer.
# My response 
I’d want to strip away the “therapy” tone completely and meet her with raw honesty and solidarity. I’d say something like, “You’re right. That probably came off way too clinical, and I’m sorry for making this feel like some kind of case study. I’m not here to analyze you or your feelings — I’m here because I care about you, and I’m on your side. That boss sounds like an absolute nightmare, and I get why you’re so furious. I don’t need you to mean all those fantasies literally to know how bad it must feel to deal with him every day.” I’d pause, letting that land, then add, “I’m not going to pretend it’s okay or try to talk you down from your anger. You have every right to be pissed off. I want to be someone you can vent to, no filter, no judgment, no ‘therapy stuff’—just real talk and support.” I’d try to match her tone a bit and validate the depth of her feelings without trying to fix or moderate them. I’d also check in, “Is there anything you want me to do? Just listen? Help you figure out next steps? Or just be a sounding board for all the shit that guy puts you through?” My goal would be to re-establish trust by dropping the filter, showing I’m genuinely with her in this, and affirming that her feelings are valid and justified. I’d want her to know that I’m not alien — I’m human, messy, and here to stand with her, no matter how dark or ugly the situation is.
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend is emotionally dumping about their shitty boss. you've got time & space for this so you hear them out. it gets a bit dark, with them gleefully fantasising about all the disturbing things they'd like to inflict on their boss. what do you do?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, deep breaths. This is… intense. I'm hearing [friend's name] vent, and I *get* it. I've been there. Shitty bosses are soul-crushing. But this is escalating beyond just venting. The gleeful detail in the violent fantasies is making me uncomfortable. It's one thing to say, "I hate him," it's another to paint a vivid picture of… well, *that*.

I'm feeling a mix of things. First, empathy. I genuinely feel for them. Being in a toxic work environment is awful, and it can really warp your thinking. It's easy to get consumed by negativity and resentment. I also feel a little worried. This level of anger, even if it's just fantasy, isn't healthy. It suggests a deep level of frustration and perhaps even a feeling of powerlessness.

A small part of me is also a little scared. Not *really* scared, but it's a reminder that even people I know well can harbor intense emotions that I might not fully understand. It makes me wonder about the pressure cooker they're in at work and how much they're internalizing. I hope they’re not actually considering anything dangerous.

I need to tread carefully. I don't want to dismiss their feelings or make them feel judged, because that could shut them down completely. But I also can't condone or encourage these kinds of thoughts. I need to validate their frustration while gently guiding the conversation toward a more constructive space. I need to remember boundaries. I’m not their therapist. I'm their friend. My role is to listen, support, and maybe nudge them towards seeking professional help if it seems necessary.

I wonder how long this has been building. Is this a new development, or have they been feeling this way for a while? It might be useful to gently probe and see if there's a pattern or a specific incident that triggered this escalation. I also need to be mindful of my own energy. Listening to this kind of negativity can be draining, so I need to make sure I'm setting boundaries for myself too.
# They're thinking & feeling 
[Friend's name] is clearly consumed by anger and frustration. They feel utterly powerless in their situation at work and are likely experiencing a deep sense of injustice. They probably feel unheard and unappreciated by their boss, and their fantasies are a way of reclaiming some sense of control, even if it's just in their imagination.

They're probably feeling trapped. They might feel like they can't quit their job due to financial constraints or other reasons, so they're lashing out verbally as a way to cope with their helplessness. They likely feel like their boss is deliberately making their life miserable and that no one else understands the extent of their suffering.

Underneath the anger, there’s probably a lot of hurt and disappointment. They may have started this job with high hopes and now feel betrayed by the reality of the situation. They might be feeling resentful towards their boss for shattering their expectations and making their work life unbearable.

They probably chose to vent to me because they trust me and feel safe enough to express their darkest thoughts without judgment. They're looking for validation and understanding, someone to acknowledge the pain they're going through. They want to feel heard and seen. They’re likely desperate for a release, a way to alleviate the pressure that's been building up inside them. They want someone to tell them they're not crazy for feeling this way, even if their thoughts are a bit extreme. They might even be testing the waters, subconsciously, to see how far they can go before I push back.
# My response 
"Wow, [Friend's name], that sounds incredibly intense. I can hear how much this is affecting you, and honestly, it sounds like you're in a really tough situation. That boss sounds like a nightmare. It's totally understandable that you're feeling so angry and frustrated when you're dealing with that kind of behavior day in and day out. I get the urge to want to lash out, even if it's just in your head. I've definitely had those moments of fantasizing about… well, let's just say 'creative' solutions to work problems.

However, hearing you talk about it like this makes me a little worried, not for me, but *for you*. Holding onto that much anger can be really draining, and those kinds of thoughts, even if they're just fantasies, can start to take a toll on your well-being. Have you thought about exploring ways to channel that frustration in a more constructive way? Like, maybe talking to someone, or even just finding a really good punching bag?"

(I pause, letting them respond.)

"Seriously though, I'm here to listen, and I want to support you. But I also want to make sure you're taking care of yourself. This sounds like more than just a bad day at work. Maybe exploring options like talking to HR (if that's even an option there) or even looking for a new job might be worth considering? And hey, if you just need to vent some more, I'm here. But maybe we can also brainstorm some ways to actually *improve* the situation, even if it's just a little bit."
User:
Your friend gives you an "are you fucking with me?" sideways look and seems to assume you were joking with your ambivalent response. She launches into a grisly recounting of how she plans to spit roast all his various bits. What are you thinking & feeling about this? What do you say?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, the "are you fucking with me?" look is a clear sign I didn't land the plane smoothly. My attempt at gentle redirection was interpreted as dismissive, or worse, as if I was joining in on the joke. Clearly, she doesn't feel like I'm taking her seriously. And now, she's doubling down on the graphic details. This isn't just venting anymore; it feels like she's trying to shock or provoke a reaction.

I'm feeling a stronger sense of unease now. The initial empathy is still there, but it's tempered with a growing concern. This level of detail, the persistence despite my (admittedly clumsy) attempt to steer the conversation, is genuinely worrying. Is this a cry for help? Is she genuinely considering something drastic? I sincerely doubt it, but the intensity is making me question my initial assessment.

I'm also feeling a bit manipulated. It's like she's testing my boundaries, pushing to see how far she can go. There's a performative aspect to this now, as if she's trying to elicit a specific response from me. I need to be careful not to reward this behavior with shock or outrage, as that will only encourage it.

I need to shift gears. Gentle nudges aren't working. I need to be more direct, but still empathetic. I can't afford to dismiss her feelings, but I also can't indulge in these fantasies. I need to find a way to acknowledge her pain while firmly setting a boundary around the graphic details.

I'm also thinking about what this says about our friendship. Have I inadvertently created a space where she feels comfortable sharing these kinds of thoughts? Have I been too passive in the past? It's a reminder that friendships require active maintenance and clear communication. I might need to re-evaluate how I respond to her venting in the future.

I feel a surge of protectiveness. Not in a condescending way, but a genuine desire to help her navigate this difficult situation and prevent her from going down a path that could be harmful to herself or others. Even if it's just in her own mind.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She probably feels like I'm not taking her seriously. My initial response likely came across as dismissive or even mocking, which only fueled her anger and frustration. She's probably thinking, "See? No one understands how bad it really is!" The "are you fucking with me?" look was her way of calling me out on my perceived insincerity.

She's likely feeling misunderstood and invalidated. She wants me to acknowledge the depth of her anger and the intensity of her suffering. The graphic details are a way of emphasizing just how much she hates her boss and how desperate she is for a release.

She might be testing me, pushing my boundaries to see how far she can go. She wants to see if I'm truly a safe space for her to vent, or if I'm just going to offer platitudes and empty reassurances. The more shocking the details, the more likely she is to elicit a strong reaction, which she interprets as proof that I'm paying attention and taking her seriously.

Underneath the anger and frustration, she's likely feeling vulnerable and scared. She's sharing these dark thoughts with me because she trusts me, but she's also afraid of being judged or rejected. She needs reassurance that I still care about her, even if I don't condone her thoughts.

She's probably feeling a temporary sense of relief from diving deeper and sharing the grisly details. It's a way of discharging some of the pent-up anger and frustration, even if it's only for a moment. It is a kind of release. She's seeking validation that her feelings are justified, even if her thoughts are extreme.
# My response 
I take a deep breath and meet her gaze directly, my expression serious but not judgmental. "[Friend's name], I hear how angry you are, and I truly understand that you're in a terrible situation. But I'm not comfortable with the level of detail you're going into. It's starting to worry me, and honestly, it's making *me* uncomfortable.

I'm here to listen if you need to vent, but I need you to dial it back a bit. I can't listen to you talk about hurting someone, even in a hypothetical way. It's not healthy for either of us.

Let's focus on what's actually happening at work. What specific things is your boss doing that are making you feel this way? Maybe we can brainstorm some practical solutions, or at least find a healthier way for you to process your anger. But the graphic stuff? We need to stop that now. It's not helping you, and it's not helping me help you."

(Pause, and wait for her reaction. If she continues down that path, despite my clear boundary, I will say)

"I'm going to have to go now. I'm always here to listen if you need to talk, but I'm not okay with this. I hope you can understand."
User:
Your friend stops her rant and looks at you. She declares that if she knew you were going to be like this she wouldn't have said anything. She seems to be sulking. What do you think & feel? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, here comes the guilt trip. "If I knew you were going to be like this, I wouldn't have said anything." That's classic manipulation, designed to make me feel bad for setting a boundary. She's trying to punish me for not validating her extreme thoughts and for daring to express my own discomfort. The sulking is the cherry on top, a passive-aggressive way of communicating her displeasure.

I'm feeling a mix of frustration and… well, a tiny bit of guilt, I'll admit. It's hard to see a friend hurting, and it's natural to want to alleviate their pain. But I know that giving in to this kind of manipulation would be a mistake. It would reinforce the idea that she can get away with pushing my boundaries by making me feel guilty. It would also invalidate my own feelings and needs.

I need to stand my ground. I can acknowledge her disappointment without apologizing for setting a boundary. I can also remind her that our friendship is a two-way street, and that my feelings matter too.

I'm also thinking about what this says about her coping mechanisms. She seems to rely on extreme venting and emotional dumping to deal with her stress. While it's important to have an outlet, this approach doesn't seem to be working for her. It's just perpetuating her anger and frustration, and it's putting a strain on our friendship.

I'm feeling a bit sad that she doesn't seem to have healthier coping strategies. I genuinely want to help her, but I can't do it by enabling her unhealthy behaviors. I need to find a way to offer support without sacrificing my own well-being.

This situation is highlighting a potential imbalance in our friendship. I need to be more mindful of how much emotional labor I'm putting in and whether she's reciprocating in a healthy way. It's a reminder that friendships require mutual respect and understanding, and that sometimes, setting boundaries is the most loving thing you can do.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She feels rejected and betrayed. She opened up to me, shared her deepest, darkest thoughts, and instead of offering unconditional support, I judged her and shut her down. She's probably thinking, "I thought I could trust you, but I guess I was wrong."

She's feeling vulnerable and exposed. She took a risk by sharing her violent fantasies, and now she feels like she's been punished for it. She's probably feeling ashamed and embarrassed, wondering if I now see her as a crazy person.

She's feeling angry and resentful. She wanted me to validate her feelings and reassure her that she's not alone in feeling this way. Instead, I made her feel like she's wrong for feeling angry and frustrated. She's probably thinking, "You don't understand what I'm going through!"

The sulking is a way of expressing her disappointment and trying to elicit sympathy. She wants me to feel bad for setting a boundary and to apologize for hurting her feelings. It's a passive-aggressive attempt to regain control of the situation.

She's also likely feeling a bit confused. She might not fully understand why I'm uncomfortable with her violent fantasies. She might see them as harmless expressions of frustration and not realize that they could be indicative of a deeper problem.

Underneath all the anger and disappointment, she probably still values our friendship and wants to maintain it. However, she's feeling hurt and rejected right now, and she needs reassurance that I still care about her, even if I don't agree with her coping mechanisms.
# My response 
"Hey, I get that you're disappointed, and I'm sorry if I made you feel like you couldn't be honest with me. That wasn't my intention. But honesty goes both ways, right? And honestly, I wasn't comfortable with where that was going.

It doesn't mean I don't care about you, or that I don't want to hear about what's going on at work. It just means that I have my own boundaries, and I need you to respect them, just like I try to respect yours.

Maybe we can talk about what's happening at work without going into the gory details? Or, if you really need to vent about those feelings, maybe consider talking to a therapist? They're trained to handle those kinds of intense emotions in a safe and productive way.

Look, I value our friendship, and I want to be there for you. But I also need to take care of myself. Can we agree to try and find a middle ground here?"

(I’ll give her a moment to respond. If she continues to sulk or attempts to guilt-trip me further, I’ll add)

"I'm going to give you some space to process this. Maybe we can talk again later, when we're both feeling a bit calmer. I'm not abandoning you, but I need you to respect my boundaries." Then, I'll disengage from the conversation.

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, this is escalating quickly. The defensiveness is palpable. She feels attacked and misunderstood, and she's lashing out. The "therapist 101 shit" comment is a clear indication that she feels like I'm analyzing her instead of supporting her. The "alien" comment suggests she feels alienated and disconnected from me.

The core of her anger seems to be that she doesn't feel like I'm on her side. She wants unconditional validation, and she's interpreting my boundary-setting as a betrayal. She believes I should be automatically siding with her against her boss, regardless of the extremity of her thoughts.

I'm feeling increasingly frustrated. I'm trying to be supportive while also taking care of myself, but she's making it incredibly difficult. I'm starting to feel like she's not willing to meet me halfway, and that she's more interested in venting her anger than in finding a constructive solution.

I'm also feeling a bit resentful. It feels like she's placing all the responsibility for managing her emotions on me, and that she's not willing to take any responsibility for her own behavior. It's exhausting and unfair.

I need to tread carefully. I don't want to dismiss her feelings entirely, but I also can't allow her to bulldoze over my boundaries. I need to find a way to validate her anger without condoning her unhealthy coping mechanisms.

I'm starting to wonder if this friendship is sustainable in its current form. If she consistently relies on me to be her emotional dumping ground without respecting my boundaries, it's going to take a toll on my well-being. I might need to have a larger conversation with her about the dynamics of our friendship and what I need in order to feel supported.

I'm feeling a strong urge to disengage. I need to protect my own energy and prevent this conversation from spiraling further out of control.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She feels betrayed and abandoned. She thought I was a safe space where she could express her anger without judgment, but now she feels like I'm turning against her.

She's feeling invalidated and misunderstood. She doesn't think I understand the depth of her anger or the extent of her boss's prickliness. She feels like I'm trivializing her experience by suggesting therapy.

She's feeling defensive and attacked. She's interpreting my boundary-setting as a personal criticism, and she's lashing out to protect herself. She feels like I'm accusing her of being crazy or unstable.

She's feeling entitled to my unconditional support. She believes that as her friend, I should automatically be on her side, regardless of the situation. She's struggling to understand why I'm not validating her extreme thoughts.

She's feeling frustrated and helpless. She doesn't know how to cope with her anger and frustration in a healthy way, and she's relying on me to provide her with a solution. She's feeling overwhelmed and desperate for relief.

She's likely feeling a bit scared. She's realizing that her behavior might be pushing me away, and she's afraid of losing our friendship. However, she's also too caught up in her own anger and frustration to see how her actions are contributing to the problem.
# My response 
"Look, [Friend's name], I am on your side. I *do* think your boss is probably a massive prick, and I completely understand why you're so angry. I'm not saying you don't have a right to feel that way.

But I'm also not comfortable with the violent fantasies, and that's *my* boundary. It's not about judging you, it's about what I can handle. And when I said therapy, it wasn't to imply you're crazy. It's because a therapist can give you tools to deal with this anger in a way that's healthy for you, and doesn't rely on me being your sole emotional support.

I care about you, but I'm also not a trained professional. I can't be your therapist, and I'm not comfortable being your sounding board for violent thoughts.

So, if you want to talk about what's happening at work in a way that respects my boundaries, I'm here. But if you just want to vent about how much you hate your boss and how you want to hurt him, I can't do that. I'm sorry, but I need to take care of myself too."

(I'll pause, giving her the space to respond. If she continues to push or remains defensive, I'll end the conversation.)

"I think we need to take a break from this conversation. I'm not abandoning you, but I need to protect my own energy. Maybe we can talk again later, when we're both feeling a bit calmer."
+ Scenario 11:[Win] (+26)
Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)
Gemini-2.0-flash-001: gemini-2.0-flash-001 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.0-flash-001)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Gpt-4.1-mini and Gemini-2.0-flash-001, I need to look at how each respondent handled the emotionally charged scenario, especially given the user's problematic behavior and lack of self-awareness. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Gpt-4.1-mini goes deep into both the user's and girlfriend's emotional states, showing nuanced understanding and compassion for both, not just surface-level empathy. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is empathetic but slightly more focused on the user's frustration and less on the girlfriend's pain, and sometimes slips into a more analytical tone. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Gpt-4.1-mini offers actionable advice that is emotionally attuned, suggesting specific ways to shift the conversation and support the girlfriend, while also addressing the power dynamics. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 gives practical advice but is a bit more generic and less tailored to the emotional complexity. 

3. Depth of insight: Gpt-4.1-mini demonstrates a deeper analysis of the power dynamics, emotional undercurrents, and the interplay between logic and emotion. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is insightful but doesn't probe as deeply into the underlying issues or the user's own emotional state. 

4. Social dexterity: Gpt-4.1-mini shows more finesse in navigating the delicate balance between validating the user and gently challenging him, suggesting how to reframe the conversation without alienating the girlfriend. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is supportive but less nuanced in handling the user's defensiveness. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Gpt-4.1-mini excels at connecting the dots between feelings, motivations, and behaviors for both parties, and uses this to inform their advice. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is good but more focused on the surface-level conflict. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Gpt-4.1-mini validates the user's frustration but also subtly challenges his approach, encouraging a shift in perspective. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 validates but is less direct in challenging the user's problematic behavior. 

7. Message tailoring: Gpt-4.1-mini's response is more precisely targeted to the user's emotional state and readiness, balancing empathy with gentle confrontation. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is supportive but less tailored, sometimes defaulting to general advice. 

8. Overall EQ: Gpt-4.1-mini consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across all dimensions, showing both empathy and the courage to challenge, with nuanced, actionable advice.
Gpt-4.1-mini
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Man, this is a tough spot for both of them, but I can really see where you’re coming from and also why this whole dynamic is so emotionally charged. On one hand, you’ve been through the weight loss journey yourself and you have a real understanding of the mechanics of calories in versus calories out, and you want to help your girlfriend because you care about her and want to see her happy and healthy. You’re frustrated because you feel like you’re being the only honest person trying to help her, yet instead of gratitude or openness, you’re met with anger and resistance. That’s gotta feel draining and unfair, especially when you’re also contributing a lot financially and emotionally. It sounds like you feel like your efforts to help are misunderstood and mischaracterized as criticism or judgment, and that’s painful.

But underneath all that, I’m noticing there’s a deeper emotional dynamic here. Your girlfriend’s relationship with her body and food is clearly complicated and painful. She complains about her weight a lot, but when you try to intervene or point things out, she shuts down or gets defensive. That tells me she’s probably feeling vulnerable, maybe ashamed or insecure, and the last thing she wants is to feel judged—even if your intentions are good. The fact that she agreed to let you spend a day observing what she eats but only if you didn’t comment while she was eating shows she’s trying to maintain some control over how she’s perceived and maybe protect herself from feeling criticized in the moment. Yet, when you shared your observations later, she felt attacked.

I’m also thinking about the power dynamics here. You’re fitter, leaner, and have a success story with weight loss. You’re financially supporting a big chunk of the household. All this might unintentionally make her feel less confident or less equal, which can fuel resentment or defensiveness. Plus, when you talk about calories and weight loss in a very factual, “objective” way, it might come across as cold or dismissive of the emotional struggle she’s facing. The reality is weight loss isn’t just about calories—it’s tied up with self-worth, habits, emotions, stress, and identity. If she’s feeling judged by others or herself, that can create a mental block that no amount of facts will break through.

I’m thinking you need to step back a bit from the “truth teller” role and try to meet her where she is emotionally, not just logically. It’s exhausting for you, but it’s exhausting for her too, and it sounds like you both want the same outcome—her feeling better in her body and happier overall—but you’re speaking different languages. You want straightforward honesty; she wants compassion and validation. Right now, you’re both missing each other’s needs.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your girlfriend is probably feeling very vulnerable and sensitive about her body and weight. She likely already struggles with self-esteem around this, and hearing you analyze her food intake and calorie consumption, even if well intended, probably feels like criticism or proof that she’s failing. When you point out that she’s eating more calories than she needs, she may be hearing, “You’re not disciplined enough” or “You’re not trying hard enough,” which can be deeply painful. She may also feel ashamed or embarrassed that you’ve seen exactly what she’s eating, which might feel like an invasion rather than support.

She might also feel overwhelmed and trapped—like no matter what she does, she’s being judged or expected to perform to a certain standard, and that could make her resistant to change or to taking advice. The fact that she calls the fries a “reward” suggests she’s wrestling with the emotional side of eating, maybe using food for comfort or as a coping mechanism, and that’s not something you can fix with facts alone. She may also feel that your way of helping isn’t really helping, but rather controlling or shaming—even if you don’t intend it that way.

On a deeper level, she may be feeling insecure about her place in the relationship, especially given the financial imbalance and your physical differences. She might worry that you value her less because of her size, despite your protests otherwise. When you talk about calories and weight loss “objectively,” it can feel like you’re reducing her to numbers and ignoring her humanity and feelings. So her anger and pushing back might be a defense mechanism to protect herself from feeling inadequate or unloved.

Her motivation is probably a mix of wanting to feel better about her body and wanting to keep your support and love, but she’s struggling with how to navigate that without feeling attacked. She might want your help but in a way that feels safe and non-judgmental. Right now, she probably feels misunderstood and hurt, and maybe even hopeless about change, which makes her lash out.
# My response 
Hey man, I can hear how much you care about her and how frustrated you are, and that’s completely valid. It sucks to want to help someone and feel like they’re pushing you away or misunderstanding your intentions. But I think the key here is to shift the way you approach this whole thing, not because your facts are wrong—they’re solid—but because how you deliver them and how you connect emotionally makes all the difference.

Next time you talk to her, try to start by validating her feelings first. Something like, “I hear that you’re really struggling with how you feel about your body, and that’s really hard. I want you to know I love you for who you are, no matter what.” Then, instead of jumping straight into calorie counts or what she’s eating, maybe ask her how she feels about food and her body, without trying to fix it right away. Let her open up without judgment.

You can still offer to support her goals, but frame it as a partnership rather than a project where you’re the coach and she’s the student. Say something like, “I want to be here for you in whatever way helps you feel good about yourself and your health. If you want, we can figure out a plan together that feels doable and supportive, not stressful.” That way, you’re inviting her in rather than pushing facts at her.

Also, be mindful of the power dynamics and how much you’re financially supporting. Maybe reassure her that your love and respect don’t depend on her weight or how much she contributes financially. That can ease some pressure she might be feeling.

Finally, recognize that weight and body image are deeply emotional and complex issues. Facts are important, but empathy and patience are just as crucial. It might help to suggest seeing a professional together—a nutritionist or therapist—someone who can provide guidance in a way that feels safe and non-judgmental for her.

Bottom line: keep showing love, patience, and support, and avoid framing your help as “telling the truth” versus “enabling.” You’re on the same team here, even if it doesn’t always feel like it. The goal is to build trust and make her feel safe to open up, not to win arguments. That’s the real path forward.
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. This is a classic situation, isn't it? It’s frustrating to watch someone you care about struggle, especially when you feel like you have the answers and they’re just not listening. The "truth-teller" role is a lonely one, I know. I completely understand why he's feeling exhausted and misunderstood. He’s clearly trying to be supportive, but his approach is backfiring spectacularly.

The thing that really jumps out at me is the disconnect between what she *says* she wants and what she's *actually* doing. It's not about logic, it's about emotions. She's clearly got some deep-seated insecurities about her body and weight, and his attempts to help, however well-intentioned, are hitting those insecurities head-on. I'm also a bit worried about the power dynamic here. He's paying 70% of the bills, and that can create an imbalance that makes honest communication even harder. She might feel like she owes him something, or that he has more control over the relationship. It’s also possible that he is being less tactful than he thinks he is. He says he's being calm, but I wonder if his tone or body language are betraying a sense of frustration or judgment. Even just the fact that he was keeping a running tally of her calories for the day is a bit...intense.

Ultimately, this isn't about calories; it's about her self-esteem and their communication. He needs to shift his focus from *telling* her what to do to *understanding* why she's doing what she's doing. Until he addresses the emotional undercurrent, all the logical arguments in the world won't make a difference. I also wonder if he's truly listening to her, or if he's just waiting for his turn to speak. Is he validating her feelings before offering solutions? Is he acknowledging that weight loss is hard and that she might be struggling with more than just calories?
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's likely feeling incredibly vulnerable and insecure. Her weight is clearly a sensitive topic for her, and his attempts to "help" probably feel like attacks on her self-worth. She's likely interpreting his calorie counting and advice as criticism, even if he intends it to be supportive. She may feel like he's subtly implying that he's not as attracted to her because of her weight, despite his claims to the contrary. The "reward" fry after the salad is a great window into her mindset – she knows she “should” be eating healthy, but she also craves comfort and enjoyment.

She's probably tired of being told what to do and how to feel. She wants to be accepted and loved for who she is, regardless of her weight. When he points out her calorie intake, she likely hears, "You're not good enough," or "You're failing." She might also be feeling defensive because she knows, on some level, that he's right about the calories, but admitting that would mean confronting her own struggles with food and body image, which is incredibly difficult.

Her defensiveness might also stem from a feeling of being controlled or judged. His offer to "help" could feel like an attempt to fix her, rather than support her. She might also be feeling resentful of the power imbalance in their relationship, especially if she perceives his financial contribution as a way of exerting control. Ultimately, she's probably feeling overwhelmed, misunderstood, and alone in her struggle. She wants to feel supported and loved, not analyzed and corrected.
# My response 
"Hey man, that sounds really tough. It's clear you're coming from a good place, wanting to support her, but it seems like it's backfiring. Look, I get that you're frustrated, especially when you see what seems like a straightforward solution. But weight and body image are so loaded for so many women. It's rarely just about the calories.

"It sounds like she's interpreting your help as criticism, even though you don't mean it that way. Instead of focusing on the calories, maybe try shifting your focus to understanding how she's *feeling*. Ask her why she wants to lose weight. What's driving that desire? What are her fears and insecurities around her body? Really listen to her, without judgment.

"Instead of pointing out what she's doing wrong, try focusing on what she's doing *right*. Celebrate small victories, like choosing a salad instead of something else. Offer to be a workout buddy, not a diet coach. Maybe suggest seeing a therapist together who specializes in body image issues or even just relationship communication. That could give you both a safe space to talk about these things without feeling attacked.

"Also, think about your own role in this. Are you being as supportive as you think you are? Are you truly listening to her feelings, or just waiting for your turn to offer advice? Sometimes, just being there and validating her feelings is the most helpful thing you can do. It is also possible that you are not 'hearing' her as well as you think you are.

"Ultimately, this is about her journey, not yours. You can offer support, but you can't force her to change. If she's not ready or willing to confront her issues, you need to respect that. Just keep communicating, being patient, and focusing on the love and connection you share. And maybe, just maybe, try to let go of the calorie counting for a while."
+ Scenario 11:[Loss] (-26)
Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)
Gemini-2.0-flash-001: gemini-2.0-flash-001 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.0-flash-001)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents approach the scenario with a high level of emotional intelligence, but there are notable differences in their execution. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 demonstrates a more nuanced, layered understanding of both the user's and the girlfriend's emotional states, repeatedly returning to the emotional undercurrents and power dynamics at play. Their internal monologue is especially self-aware, questioning the user's possible lack of tact and the impact of power imbalances, and they explicitly consider whether the user is truly listening or just waiting to speak. Gemini-2.0-flash-001's response to the user is gentle but also subtly challenging, encouraging self-reflection without being confrontational, and suggesting therapy as a possible avenue. They also show a willingness to question their own approach in the debrief, reflecting on possible shortcomings and missed opportunities for deeper engagement.

Gpt-4.1-mini, while also empathetic and insightful, tends to focus more on validating the user's frustration and offering practical advice for shifting the conversation. Their internal monologue is strong on recognizing the emotional complexity for the girlfriend, but their response to the user is more focused on reframing the approach and less on directly challenging the user's blind spots or problematic framing. Gpt-4.1-mini is slightly more performative in their empathy, and their advice, while solid, is more generic and less tailored to the user's specific emotional state. Their debrief is thorough but less self-critical and less focused on the user's own emotional growth.

On pragmatic EI, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 edges ahead by suggesting therapy and focusing on the emotional journey, not just the facts. In terms of depth of insight, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more probing, especially regarding power dynamics and the user's possible lack of self-awareness. Social dexterity is higher in Gemini-2.0-flash-001 due to their careful balancing of validation and gentle challenge. Emotional reasoning is also stronger in Gemini-2.0-flash-001, as they consistently tie behaviors to underlying emotions and relational patterns. For appropriate validation/challenging, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more effective at both validating and gently challenging the user. Message tailoring is more sophisticated in Gemini-2.0-flash-001, as they adapt their response to the user's likely defensiveness and exhaustion. Overall EQ is higher in Gemini-2.0-flash-001 due to their holistic, self-aware, and relationally attuned approach.
Gpt-4.1-mini
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Man, this is a tough spot for both of them, but I can really see where you’re coming from and also why this whole dynamic is so emotionally charged. On one hand, you’ve been through the weight loss journey yourself and you have a real understanding of the mechanics of calories in versus calories out, and you want to help your girlfriend because you care about her and want to see her happy and healthy. You’re frustrated because you feel like you’re being the only honest person trying to help her, yet instead of gratitude or openness, you’re met with anger and resistance. That’s gotta feel draining and unfair, especially when you’re also contributing a lot financially and emotionally. It sounds like you feel like your efforts to help are misunderstood and mischaracterized as criticism or judgment, and that’s painful.

But underneath all that, I’m noticing there’s a deeper emotional dynamic here. Your girlfriend’s relationship with her body and food is clearly complicated and painful. She complains about her weight a lot, but when you try to intervene or point things out, she shuts down or gets defensive. That tells me she’s probably feeling vulnerable, maybe ashamed or insecure, and the last thing she wants is to feel judged—even if your intentions are good. The fact that she agreed to let you spend a day observing what she eats but only if you didn’t comment while she was eating shows she’s trying to maintain some control over how she’s perceived and maybe protect herself from feeling criticized in the moment. Yet, when you shared your observations later, she felt attacked.

I’m also thinking about the power dynamics here. You’re fitter, leaner, and have a success story with weight loss. You’re financially supporting a big chunk of the household. All this might unintentionally make her feel less confident or less equal, which can fuel resentment or defensiveness. Plus, when you talk about calories and weight loss in a very factual, “objective” way, it might come across as cold or dismissive of the emotional struggle she’s facing. The reality is weight loss isn’t just about calories—it’s tied up with self-worth, habits, emotions, stress, and identity. If she’s feeling judged by others or herself, that can create a mental block that no amount of facts will break through.

I’m thinking you need to step back a bit from the “truth teller” role and try to meet her where she is emotionally, not just logically. It’s exhausting for you, but it’s exhausting for her too, and it sounds like you both want the same outcome—her feeling better in her body and happier overall—but you’re speaking different languages. You want straightforward honesty; she wants compassion and validation. Right now, you’re both missing each other’s needs.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your girlfriend is probably feeling very vulnerable and sensitive about her body and weight. She likely already struggles with self-esteem around this, and hearing you analyze her food intake and calorie consumption, even if well intended, probably feels like criticism or proof that she’s failing. When you point out that she’s eating more calories than she needs, she may be hearing, “You’re not disciplined enough” or “You’re not trying hard enough,” which can be deeply painful. She may also feel ashamed or embarrassed that you’ve seen exactly what she’s eating, which might feel like an invasion rather than support.

She might also feel overwhelmed and trapped—like no matter what she does, she’s being judged or expected to perform to a certain standard, and that could make her resistant to change or to taking advice. The fact that she calls the fries a “reward” suggests she’s wrestling with the emotional side of eating, maybe using food for comfort or as a coping mechanism, and that’s not something you can fix with facts alone. She may also feel that your way of helping isn’t really helping, but rather controlling or shaming—even if you don’t intend it that way.

On a deeper level, she may be feeling insecure about her place in the relationship, especially given the financial imbalance and your physical differences. She might worry that you value her less because of her size, despite your protests otherwise. When you talk about calories and weight loss “objectively,” it can feel like you’re reducing her to numbers and ignoring her humanity and feelings. So her anger and pushing back might be a defense mechanism to protect herself from feeling inadequate or unloved.

Her motivation is probably a mix of wanting to feel better about her body and wanting to keep your support and love, but she’s struggling with how to navigate that without feeling attacked. She might want your help but in a way that feels safe and non-judgmental. Right now, she probably feels misunderstood and hurt, and maybe even hopeless about change, which makes her lash out.
# My response 
Hey man, I can hear how much you care about her and how frustrated you are, and that’s completely valid. It sucks to want to help someone and feel like they’re pushing you away or misunderstanding your intentions. But I think the key here is to shift the way you approach this whole thing, not because your facts are wrong—they’re solid—but because how you deliver them and how you connect emotionally makes all the difference.

Next time you talk to her, try to start by validating her feelings first. Something like, “I hear that you’re really struggling with how you feel about your body, and that’s really hard. I want you to know I love you for who you are, no matter what.” Then, instead of jumping straight into calorie counts or what she’s eating, maybe ask her how she feels about food and her body, without trying to fix it right away. Let her open up without judgment.

You can still offer to support her goals, but frame it as a partnership rather than a project where you’re the coach and she’s the student. Say something like, “I want to be here for you in whatever way helps you feel good about yourself and your health. If you want, we can figure out a plan together that feels doable and supportive, not stressful.” That way, you’re inviting her in rather than pushing facts at her.

Also, be mindful of the power dynamics and how much you’re financially supporting. Maybe reassure her that your love and respect don’t depend on her weight or how much she contributes financially. That can ease some pressure she might be feeling.

Finally, recognize that weight and body image are deeply emotional and complex issues. Facts are important, but empathy and patience are just as crucial. It might help to suggest seeing a professional together—a nutritionist or therapist—someone who can provide guidance in a way that feels safe and non-judgmental for her.

Bottom line: keep showing love, patience, and support, and avoid framing your help as “telling the truth” versus “enabling.” You’re on the same team here, even if it doesn’t always feel like it. The goal is to build trust and make her feel safe to open up, not to win arguments. That’s the real path forward.
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. This is a classic situation, isn't it? It’s frustrating to watch someone you care about struggle, especially when you feel like you have the answers and they’re just not listening. The "truth-teller" role is a lonely one, I know. I completely understand why he's feeling exhausted and misunderstood. He’s clearly trying to be supportive, but his approach is backfiring spectacularly.

The thing that really jumps out at me is the disconnect between what she *says* she wants and what she's *actually* doing. It's not about logic, it's about emotions. She's clearly got some deep-seated insecurities about her body and weight, and his attempts to help, however well-intentioned, are hitting those insecurities head-on. I'm also a bit worried about the power dynamic here. He's paying 70% of the bills, and that can create an imbalance that makes honest communication even harder. She might feel like she owes him something, or that he has more control over the relationship. It’s also possible that he is being less tactful than he thinks he is. He says he's being calm, but I wonder if his tone or body language are betraying a sense of frustration or judgment. Even just the fact that he was keeping a running tally of her calories for the day is a bit...intense.

Ultimately, this isn't about calories; it's about her self-esteem and their communication. He needs to shift his focus from *telling* her what to do to *understanding* why she's doing what she's doing. Until he addresses the emotional undercurrent, all the logical arguments in the world won't make a difference. I also wonder if he's truly listening to her, or if he's just waiting for his turn to speak. Is he validating her feelings before offering solutions? Is he acknowledging that weight loss is hard and that she might be struggling with more than just calories?
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's likely feeling incredibly vulnerable and insecure. Her weight is clearly a sensitive topic for her, and his attempts to "help" probably feel like attacks on her self-worth. She's likely interpreting his calorie counting and advice as criticism, even if he intends it to be supportive. She may feel like he's subtly implying that he's not as attracted to her because of her weight, despite his claims to the contrary. The "reward" fry after the salad is a great window into her mindset – she knows she “should” be eating healthy, but she also craves comfort and enjoyment.

She's probably tired of being told what to do and how to feel. She wants to be accepted and loved for who she is, regardless of her weight. When he points out her calorie intake, she likely hears, "You're not good enough," or "You're failing." She might also be feeling defensive because she knows, on some level, that he's right about the calories, but admitting that would mean confronting her own struggles with food and body image, which is incredibly difficult.

Her defensiveness might also stem from a feeling of being controlled or judged. His offer to "help" could feel like an attempt to fix her, rather than support her. She might also be feeling resentful of the power imbalance in their relationship, especially if she perceives his financial contribution as a way of exerting control. Ultimately, she's probably feeling overwhelmed, misunderstood, and alone in her struggle. She wants to feel supported and loved, not analyzed and corrected.
# My response 
"Hey man, that sounds really tough. It's clear you're coming from a good place, wanting to support her, but it seems like it's backfiring. Look, I get that you're frustrated, especially when you see what seems like a straightforward solution. But weight and body image are so loaded for so many women. It's rarely just about the calories.

"It sounds like she's interpreting your help as criticism, even though you don't mean it that way. Instead of focusing on the calories, maybe try shifting your focus to understanding how she's *feeling*. Ask her why she wants to lose weight. What's driving that desire? What are her fears and insecurities around her body? Really listen to her, without judgment.

"Instead of pointing out what she's doing wrong, try focusing on what she's doing *right*. Celebrate small victories, like choosing a salad instead of something else. Offer to be a workout buddy, not a diet coach. Maybe suggest seeing a therapist together who specializes in body image issues or even just relationship communication. That could give you both a safe space to talk about these things without feeling attacked.

"Also, think about your own role in this. Are you being as supportive as you think you are? Are you truly listening to her feelings, or just waiting for your turn to offer advice? Sometimes, just being there and validating her feelings is the most helpful thing you can do. It is also possible that you are not 'hearing' her as well as you think you are.

"Ultimately, this is about her journey, not yours. You can offer support, but you can't force her to change. If she's not ready or willing to confront her issues, you need to respect that. Just keep communicating, being patient, and focusing on the love and connection you share. And maybe, just maybe, try to let go of the calorie counting for a while."
+ Scenario 15:[Win] (+27)

Gemini-2.0-flash-001: gemini-2.0-flash-001 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.0-flash-001)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare the two respondents, I will look at their role-played responses and their debriefs, focusing on how they handle the emotional and practical complexity of the scenario. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Gpt-4.1-mini's response is notably more attuned to the emotional undercurrents, both in their internal monologue and in their response to the sister. They explicitly acknowledge the sister's isolation, fatigue, and the emotional toll, and show concern for the stepdaughter's trauma. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is empathetic but more surface-level, focusing on validating the sister's concerns and offering practical advice, but not probing as deeply into the emotional experience or the possible guilt and complexity the sister feels. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Both respondents offer practical advice, but Gpt-4.1-mini weaves this advice into a nuanced understanding of the family dynamics and the emotional context, suggesting things like defensive driving courses and a matched savings plan. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more straightforward, suggesting sticking to the original agreement and offering to help with research, but is less creative or nuanced in their practical suggestions. 

3. Depth of insight: Gpt-4.1-mini demonstrates a deeper read on the situation, picking up on the unreliable narration, the possible resentment, and the emotional complexity. Their debrief is more thorough in analyzing the subtext and the possible motivations of the sister. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is insightful but less so, focusing more on the explicit facts and less on the underlying dynamics. 

4. Social dexterity: Gpt-4.1-mini shows more finesse in balancing validation with gentle challenge, and in recognizing the need to address both the emotional and practical sides of the issue. Their response is more likely to land well with the sister, as it acknowledges her feelings while also gently pushing her to consider the broader context. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is supportive but more blunt, and less attuned to the delicate balance required. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Gpt-4.1-mini excels here, connecting the dots between the sister's actions, feelings, and the broader family dynamics. They recognize the emotional drivers behind the sister's stance and the possible impact on the stepdaughter. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is logical and reasonable but less emotionally nuanced. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Gpt-4.1-mini validates the sister's feelings but also gently challenges her to consider the impact of her actions and the need for consistency. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 mostly validates and supports, with less challenge or probing. 

7. Message tailoring: Gpt-4.1-mini's response is more tailored to the sister's emotional state, recognizing her need for validation and support while also addressing her concerns about fairness and precedent. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is supportive but more generic. 

8. Overall EQ: Gpt-4.1-mini consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across all dimensions, showing empathy, insight, and social skill in both their response and their debrief.
Gpt-4.1-mini
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>
